messageBody:
Michael Silverstein wrote:
> Dave Astels wrote:
>
>>OK. It's on my list. To help me focus it better, I would appreciate
>>input from the community with regard to what questions you would like to
>>see answered/explored.
>>
>
>
> Dave:
>
> Since we've been talking about making improvements to JUnit and most users
> of JUnit already understand the framework to some degree, this looks like a
> golden opportunity to explore, and certainly a concrete example of how one
> would apply TDD to the task of refactoring or improving an existing
> framework.
>
> A good approach to an article would be to select some improvement to JUnit
> and then make that improvement right there in the article, while
> illustrating how TDD is used within the process.
>
> I'd be happy to work with you on this, since I have existing needs for
> changes and I've already specified them to some degree with tests.

How about starting by associating the TestCase/TestSuite contracts with
explicit interfaces. That way you strengthen the API, removing
dependencies on those two classes.

The refactoring would be done by creating the interfaces, and then
having those two classes implement the interfaces. From there, you can
ensure that the JUnit internals work with the new interfaces (instead
of the classes). You can even write the testcases to prove that old
TestCases still work with this change.

It is doable, and it is a relatively simple refactoring that would be
suitable for an article.
